p: Ca v3.3 belongs to the family of T-type Ca 2+ channels, which are expressed in small- and medium-diameter primary afferent neurons [ 11], regulate neuronal excitability, and have a well-characterized role in neuropathic pain [ 12, 13]. Several groups have successfully demonstrated that blocking or attenuating all T-type Ca 2+ channels or, in particular, the Ca v3.2 subtype are effective strategies for mitigating behavioral signs of neuropathic pain in animal models [ 14â€“18]. In addition, the pan-T-type Ca 2+ channel blocker ethosuximide has been tested in clinical trials for neuropathic pain [ 19]. Interestingly, this particular trial was halted due to adverse events experienced by patients, suggesting that more specific Ca v3 blockers may be required for neuropathic pain.
